0FCBF42257C54CEE8325B5BBEFA55D3B.description: Discuss how creating artworks can contribute to personal well-being.

182348B5DD1D40ECBD592A1CCA449E66.description: View artworks by First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists as an inspiration for talking about art.

0516DB2FF7C9407E8021E44C62AD553D.description: Discuss how culture can be communicated through First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks

3F942FD5CAEF47AB95985333A116C685.description: Discuss the use of symmetry in ancient Greek architecture.

036E299ECB764F459B13CB0CF4C5C700.description: Examine ancient Greek artworks and architecture as an inspiration for talking about and creating art.

E3FB3249E3C54CEE80F2D38A64DCF557.description: Identify how culture may be communicated through various types of artworks.

F311755F9385416C8BFEF5BFED306226.description: A sense of community and well-being among participants can be established through First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks

0AA002DCFD9F4DA1ADEBA9BC48798048.description: Culture can be revealed through First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks.

CF6770A01BC844709AD7DE69C30E8DA3.description: Artworks from various times and places can be representative of a culture.

F702CD38B9B44ACEB355C1E72D95D35B.description: Culture is what people do, and is a way of thinking.

DFAB527903774242AED367DB28FAF35F.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks are often inspired by the natural world and stories, as seen in Bill Reid, Killer Whale, Chief of the Undersea World, c. 1984 Elsie Klengenberg, Going Down River, 1989 Jason Carter, Play Grizzly, c. 2009

90DB9B4D00A74804AB5F62C376895902.description:
Making art in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities can be holistic in nature and have individual and collective benefits, including social well-being
physical health
spiritual connection
emotional and
mental well-being
intellectual
development

004FB3E0A8AC40B7AAC46F57ACF4BAAC.description: Traditional First Nations, Métis, and Inuit art forms can include beading fish-scale art ivory and soapstone carving wood carving sculpture textiles weaving

AAC47ADAB2E04C7AB093719DC5A9966A.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artists often use materials from the natural world, including bark hide fur feathers quills sinew bones fish scales berries iron and copper roots

BBAE8DC9AADE4BA890FF53BB7D43B10F.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks can reflect aspects of culture, including history relationships ways of life traditional teachings

6BC653B097FB4508BC60ABA1F08FA3C5.description: The Parthenon is a temple in Athens that highlights symmetry length and width size and spacing of columns proportions

597E1787BBB949ED9CFAFCC502F7F30C.description: Ancient Greek architecture was inspired by the ancient Egyptians, as seen in Palace of Knossos The Lion Gate of the Palace of Agamemnon Athenian Acropolis The Agora

8923BDACCD0A4EB58B03849FCA9EFFA5.description: Ancient Greeks made very realistic sculptures of people from marble and bronze, as seen in Nike, 490 BCE Winged Victory of Samothrace, 190 BCE

5AD2A8B6708A40E3B60E7801C79F59D7.description: Ancient Greeks introduced the technique of adding wrinkles in cloth to paintings.

DAAFB0C7369743F99C50006011F2DBE2.description: In ancient Greece, artists had their own style for painting vases that usually included geometric shapes pictures of humans and animals family life stories

49E6718DAD114BCB9129B441DE2258D8.description: In ancient Greece, vases were commonly painted black and red using a feather or animal tail for a brush.

E753B4DFDAD34D8180DF8F566B9CEF36.description: Ancient Greeks valued pottery as a form of art and made vases that were admired for their beauty and function

F0124F18EBA941048D8D56F8365F659F.description: Individual components of an artwork can communicate culture, including the use of colour, line, shapes, and media.

C6AEC347B9FA4CE9800AC789A4BB754E.description: Experiences in visual arts can include learning about artworks from the past and the people who created them.

8F567A62EC06422A91355665B0864073.description: Students investigate culture in relation to artworks from ancient Greece and present day.

8AA12E0C34F34CEF88FF1F46F63E08BE.description: Students investigate culture in relation to artworks from ancient Greece and present day.

A8F89F12F7CA4FCDAC19174721F231F6.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

C7E6EE84562D480985B83E6CCB70695F.description: Add finishing touches to an artwork.

86C28AD0671B41E8B0C6DDC0A41EB38D.description: Apply creative processes when creating artworks

DA54E97E954F4C5292E025E912D74FE6.description: Create artworks that express personal preferences.

921394D2A93A44AD87844AF80FEBEC2F.description: Demonstrate an understanding of artistic protocols and etiquette within various visual arts experiences

A954E0596BC449C297E244A72DFE4921.description: Participate as an artist and audience member in various art experiences.

6D9CE54EAC5644AA84CB7AFD1A4B7544.description: Explore how to represent mood or emotion in artworks.

C8A2A8F8A3CC4855B3A1A59A1E700CDC.description: Apply principles of design to artworks.

CF959238A0114BB0B20E69588336A789.description: Make artistic choices to shape the development of a message in visual arts.

92A7CE07C8094897879E23432C9EBABE.description: Investigate how lines and shapes can form symbols that communicate a message.

7AAC1FBCF91C42E68AFE856F1AAEC412.description: Share interpretations of artworks with others

7026604C5B834C00A084F7428E9BB5EF.description: Present a title and description for an artwork that incorporates visual arts vocabulary.

4F0126902A6D411BBC9CA79F066C67CB.description: Problems related to creating art can be solved by asking for feedback and by practising.

3735D3AF6F20421EB58CE1C7190F0019.description: Messages can be clearly communicated when elements of art are combined with purpose.

300F2FE9A3AD40BFB4E14BBA558561B2.description: Development of a message in visual arts can involve creative processes

26F13A9017A845F29B0486E3CD2F3607.description: Audience members can have various feelings about artworks

F18C55E832B14A1D86304F7EBC57F083.description: The sharing of a message involves the artist and the audience.

DA4F4454DBAB4CFE8E793B771EBD961C.description: A message conveyed through visual arts can carry a variety of emotions and experiences.

68A93A90ABB34E23BDF238DE0E61CE6E.description: Non-verbal communication of a message in visual arts can be shared in a variety of ways.

529CFFFDB6964A6BB8D9C8D3F56F9147.description: A message can be communicated through spoken and written language.

1CADD68F86AA4C0EAFC0880EEB17526A.description: Artists may step back to view their artwork and discuss it with others before considering it to be finished.

C0FC469452174628BF267977E6E170AC.description: Generating an idea in visual arts may involve creative thinking and problem solving

FF5D7DBA750547A98C2A13E543BB2DFD.description: Creative processes can include generating an idea giving and receiving feedback experimentation practice reflection

C74C9CB2793149B98D909073B7872E10.description: Expectations for participating in visual arts, known as artistic protocols and etiquette, can change depending on the context of the experience.

5D3B3617657847AD9087BD5CE59809EE.description: Empathy and perspectives can be gained through creating, viewing, and talking about art.

16132303F5A84DF0AA66B4986032BFD5.description: An artwork can reflect an artist's style, which may reflect personal preferences related to creating art

DAB3078C75474FEF816EE1E33F1C671C.description: Presentations of artworks can be done through informal events, such as sharing in an art class, or formal events, including art shows or art galleries.

6420CD25EB7140489EBF44E7D7E1414A.description: A message in visual arts can be generated, sent, received, and interpreted

479F4CF2FDFF4CDBA62EB9591AD9A7E6.description:
Cultures can communicate a message through the use of ideograms pictorial symbols objects sounds etters
numbers
musical notation

27F250E672CA4707A4BF6AE009A6A475.description: Artists can choose a specific type of media to communicate how a message is revealed in artworks.

47BFD8A3359542A8B5838F82B8CC90F4.description: The physical characteristics of line can be used to represent subject matter realistically.

A776372F0ABF4CACAC4ACB4F59BECA7F.description: The mood or emotion conveyed in an artwork can be influenced by personal experiences events memories culture the use of the elements of art

CDCF37F879A847909F26FFC7DF53DB64.description: Balance, variety, and contrast (principles of design) can help guide how a message is communicated within artworks.

8E1B6FBB227144ADAD701201C9A27277.description: The elements of art can communicate a message in artworks, including the use of colour varying the physical characteristics of line adjusting value adding shapes adjusting contour of line and shape organization of line, shape, and colour adding texture

6168FC3CB39F4BA39138E66A87E8B3D2.description: Artists communicate messages about their artworks through writing about art titles talking about art using visual art vocabulary

3D3D791EAFCF408D929E6DD5707EDA4F.description: Students experiment with how messages can be communicated in and through visual arts.

D72ADA7B49DD4B2482C6EFE421472062.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge.

00C4F18F458E44A2AF482AFDA41C2A5C.description: Experiment with how shapes can be used to show depth and distance

109EED89D20F44B7A82DAFEA541AEFCB.description: Experiment with how to achieve symmetrical and asymmetrical balance in artworks.

D74A692FD44A4CB0868133A398CDBB07.description: Discuss how shapes are used within artworks to convey a message

001183C54A7B4B8583212C4ACBDF1EE0.description: Observe and discuss how variation with lines, shapes, or colours can appear in artworks.

9FBA7930C456493CA7EC31FFEAD8A506.description: Experiment with ways to use basic and complex shapes in artworks.

F95741EF31F44917A803A81BC05FB0E8.description: Analyze how complex shapes can be broken down into basic shapes.

33D2FA32F100423C913B5176CEEBB75C.description: Identify how lines and shading can be added to two-dimensional shapes to create a three-dimensional form.

2583C8C6E60E4FF99A9F93C0FBB3FFD1.description: Differentiate between two- and three-dimensional shapes.

9C77233F6F7F4D63871C60224B917BD3.description: Experiment with how shape can emerge because of contrast with other shapes, lines, values, textures, and colours.

31E9CC47F7094450A9D5487F4DD9DED6.description: Illustrate positive and negative use of shape and space.

73431E3E9E3F4D1EBF44C356DC46DF25.description: Describe how shapes can appear to be stable or moving.

726026E999414C708B4743DD55F08D30.description: Experiment with lines and shapes to draw a variety of subject matter from direct observation.

985BCC6697DB4D05B23BE1D6A613271D.description: Employ line as a way to communicate meaning in artworks.

F41209718D314B1894C312BEBF8452F5.description: Interpret what message lines can communicate in artworks

59B0340219124D99A2E193A5751EBBD7.description: Explore how lines can be used to create shading, texture, or other effects in artworks.

32569701DF894FD4AD400F8D5FDA9455.description: Incorporate a focal point in artworks.

60C8F3552DBB4C9C9146A276F79B835F.description: Create linear or onepoint perspectives in artworks.

5E954224CD4E49F08C33F411EBB3A537.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to describe how the direction of a line can lead the eye or indicate a sense of depth or distance in artworks.

8C95FF30C5CB4B6BBF1C6484C71D4FED.description: Shapes can convey meaning in the way they are organized within artworks.

EF178EB2A28B4B08B009E9F554CC5DFC.description: Shapes can be combined to create new shapes or more complex shapes.

0D94F41B13064E5E83D6C10BAF0C1304.description: Shape can be twodimensional or threedimensional.

95576D757E7847C88A90645CFEF3C8C7.description: Shape can be implied when it is not defined by an outline.

8BC32D34B62141E480EFDE3B7E98D74C.description: Line can communicate meaning in the way that it is applied in artworks.

75251A0A917C4734BCA895C770343692.description: Location of a line in artworks affects how it is perceived.

53D5C5FC8F9D4FA7B1CEBCE20D141AB8.description:
Asymmetrical balance is seen in artworks where each half of the work looks different but still has visual balance, as seen in Daphne Odjig, Tribute to the Great Chiefs of the Past, 1975 Jacques-Louis David, Oath of the Horatii, c. 1784
Ruben
Komangapik, Light
is Life, 2002

7E8EE741B5164C0B85337C1721CCECE9.description: Shapes and lines can be organized to achieve symmetrical balance in artworks and architecture, as seen in Alberta Legislature Building, Allan Merrick Jeffers and Richard Blakey,Edmonton, Alberta American 19th Century, Cutout of Animals, second quarter 19th century The Ardabil Carpet, 1539-1540

91B2FF53D50C4EF88264AEF45A49B9DC.description: Shapes can be used to represent subject matter as realistically as possible, as seen in still-life paintings? examples can include Paul C�zanne, Apples and Oranges, c. 1899 Willem van Aelst, Still Life with Flowers, c. 1665

A6C686946D7E48C3AFE0B9A2D4786521.description: Shape can create the illusion of depth and distance through techniques such as layering, overlapping, and changes in size.

4CDF72DC03E34843861C19DD5142B335.description: Basic shapes can be turned into new or complex shapes by adjusting the size adjusting the contour overlapping them connecting multiple shapes to create one shape covering parts of a shape with another

A18AF41A1F8A498FBCE2854CCB273194.description: Basic and complex use of shapes in artworks can be seen in Antoni Gaudi, El Drac, c. 1900-1914 Laurena Fineus, Ici repose, 2019 Marc Chagall, I and the Village, c. 1911 Okon Akpan Abuje, Afaha clan, Anang artist, Funerary shrine cloth, c. late 1970s

005AADEC6126432794D1263EF6717AA3.description: Variation (principle of design) can be achieved by combining shapes with other elements of art, as seen in Sandra Brewster, From Life 3, 2015 Wassily Kandinsky, Squares with Concentric Circles, c. 1913

A645DA135D38454AB60F86E763260E6A.description: Sculpture and architecture use shapes in a threedimensional context, as seen in sculpture: � Beau Dick, Moogums, 1985 � Edgar Degas, Little FourteenYear-Old Dancer, c. 1880 � Female Pwo Mask, Chokwe peoples, early 20th century � Flying Horse of Gansu, from Wuwei, China architecture: � Baitun Nur Mosque, Naseer Ahmad, Calgary, Alberta � Habitat 67, Moshe Safdie, Montreal, Quebec � Montreal Biosphere, Richard Buckminster Fuller

A7FEEBF516C543BCB3392A072CF0C311.description: A two-dimensional shape can be given a three-dimensional appearance by adding lines and shading to give the illusion of mass or volume.

6D243ADA67704A61B93A3DFB9A00BD7B.description: A two-dimensional shape can be changed into a threedimensional shape known as a form.

DDA30023C96546C4855131ACDC59A6CD.description:
Architecture in various parts of the world can depict shape, as seen Basilica de la
Sagrada Familia
by Antoni Gaudi,
under construction
since 1882
Great Stupa at
Sanchi, India,built
in the 3rd century
BCE
The Mahabodhi
Temple at Bodh
Gaya, built in the
7th and 8th century
CE

73A86E334043498EA6247FEAFAE77BE7.description: The same shape can appear to be either stable (static) or moving (dynamic) depending on how it is arranged within artworks? examples can include static: -David Smith, Cubi IX, c. 1961 dynamic: -Albert Gleizes, Brooklyn Bridge, 1915 -Bridget Riley, Amnesia, c. 1964 -Christi Belcourt, The Conversation, 2002

4123CE5B4AF14D44B934475A45FEA7B8.description: The use of positive and negative space in artworks can be seen in Alexander Calder, Lobster Trap and Fish Tail, c. 1939 André Kertész, Self-Portrait, c. 1926 Kenojuak Ashevak, Enchanted Owl, 1960 Seed Jar, Anasazi culture, c. 1150

B32A3F29980D489480587C93511B7773.description: Shape can create space in artworks, including positive-referring to the shape itself negative-referring to the space surrounding the shape

443DEDF85CE34AB8A4A696DC45FBED59.description: Shape is an enclosed space that stands out from its surroundings.

51D222F09A664FC2B813EDA29360BF77.description: A mural is a painting on a wall? examples can include Diego Rivera, The History of Medicine in Mexico, c. 1953 Lance Cardinal, Love of Nations, c. 2019

C24D677F07A743FABF936304D34278E5.description:
Lines can be used to represent subject matter as realistically as possible, as seen in Leonardo da Vinci, Portrait of a Man in Red Chalk, 1512 Rembrandt van Rijn, Cottages before a Stormy Sky, c. 1641 Rembrandt van
Rijn, Self Portrait,
Wide-Eyed, 1630
The Qingming
Scroll, c. 1100

97018826A2894A32B3BF2A86A7A52BAB.description: Direction of a line can convey a message, including the following: A horizontal line may imply serenity or stability. A diagonal line may imply agitation, motion, or instability. A vertical line may imply poise or aspiration.

05B2CABA5779493C885ED20385A31310.description: Artworks that emphasize physical characteristics of line can include A. Y. Jackson, Winter Morning, Charlevoix County, 1933 Emily Carr, SelfPortrait, 1938 Julie Mehretu, Refuge, 2007 Vincent van Gogh, The Starry Night, c. 1889

E0BA16AA5960468FBB119740922A25D4.description: Physical characteristics of line can convey emotion or character: Blurred lines may convey uncertainty. Jagged lines may convey anger. Bouncy or curvy lines may convey joyfulness.

B9793D6296474E3FAAC68928D2708D98.description: Cross-hatching is a technique that can create shading and textured effects when parallel lines are layered at right angles to each other

9FBB5ABED29444AC988EA6147404324A.description: Lines can create various effects when combined, including three-dimensional forms

AC9E2C98F1C14CB286ADA810BBBAE4F9.description: One-point perspective contains vertical or horizontal lines that recede to a vanishing point on the horizon, as seen in drawings of railroad tracks or roads that appear to vanish in the distance

45685451BE404C41BAF4D8D7EE6E6E91.description: Location of a line in an artwork can enhance or diminish its visual weight depending on where it is in the picture plane.

4BA638F726EA4FE085AF0DA9F65518FA.description: Linear perspective can create an illusion of space, depending on where lines appear

C0F07D9F8E3345CD93BFA37D2A425BAD.description: Direction of a line in artworks, including where and how it moves, can indicate a sense of depth or distance

BEC4A88C0E1A42F38E21B348E6DA2877.description:
A line can emerge when there is contrast between other lines, shapes, or colours, as seen in Jacob Lawrence,
Parade, c. 1960
Leonardo da Vinci,
Mona Lisa, c. 1503

A1D0DF289F184393930A0DFD8F0EA315.description: Emphasis (principle of design) can lead the eye to a focal point in artworks

F60B311E8A1F45379369FACDBFAF8183.description: Students examine how line and shape can communicate meaning in artworks.

BF9CB778696947CFB69D1897A90CE025.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles.
